examples.description: Zhang Zhaohui’s interactive public art installation ‘You & Me’ set up in the famous 798 Art District in Beijing China. The body shaped metal frames are adult sized with small rocks sitting at the bases to allow for easy access into the cutouts.

'Walking in Balloons' is an installation underneath the Shilin metro station in Taipei. The space is filled with one thousand inflatable cylinders that prompt people to reimagine this public space. It's also become an instant play space for kids!
Turn towering snowbanks into fun-filled mazes like this one in Sapporo, Japan! A great way for snowy winter cities to embrace their chilly identities and get people outdoors in colder months.

These flowers react to the people walking below, opening up as someone walks beneath and providing on-demand shade! They also light up at night. The intervention is improving this underutilized corner into a dynamic public space.

There is potential everywhere-- as proven by this long unchanged bridge which got a makeover by Viva Vancouver. Bright orange fabric strung underneath the Burrard Bridge is an exciting change, especially for the cyclists riding along the bike path that passes below.

'Urban Pool' offers people an unusual public space experience-- to play a game of pool with friends or strangers in an outdoor urban area. The entire table is made from concrete, allowing it to withstand weather live on as a public space amenity.

This highway underpass in Birmingham, Alabama uses a series of multi-colored, color-shifting LED lights to draw people through the space, to the neighborhoods beyond its passageway. A simple yet unique way to create landmark gateways in a city!

Talk about form revealing function. Baltimore's bus system gets a brand new stop and meeting point in the form of three giant wood-and-steel letters: B-U-S. Courtesy of collab group mmmm... and Baltimore's new Transit - Creative Placemaking program, the project creates an opportunity for social dialogue and urban renewal through playful, letter-based art.

The 'Person Parking' installation gave attendees of Milan's 2009 Public Design Festival a pocket of reprieve within a tightly packed alley. A great way to illustrate how many more bodies can fit in the space of a single unoccupied car!
Giant chess has become a popular tool! These Seattle neighbors put out their pieces for to bring some pedestrian interest to an otherwise idle curbside.
These fold-up tulip chairs in Holland pay tribute to the country's horticultural history and add some colorful pop to the landscape.
Drab parking lot meets giant gold chandelier. Now you'll never forget where you parked your car! A fun way to break up the monotony of open spaces.
Miniature Golf at The Porch, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Because we need to improve our parks and plazas if young people are to remain committed to city living and walkable suburban environments.

The TetraBIN combines the joy of playing games with the necessity for people to throw trash in the proper bin. By depositing garbage into the TetraBIN, users start a game of Tetris right on the street.

Mega-Scrabble in Seattle: Good luck hiding your tiles here. This project went the extra step and added programming to the mix, organizing an eight-team tournament to raise awareness of the First Hill neighborhood's wasted public space opportunities.
Who would have thought potholes could be so pretty! Kolomyya, Ukraine combats these urban annoyances with some floral flare, drawing attention to these decaying city streets.

Want to start a public lending library? Do as they do in Paris! Band together some recycled crates around a tree trunk and stock the shelves with leftover literature. A great pairing for plazas and playgrounds with some shade and seating!

To discourage residents from tossing their empty cups and wrappers on the streets, Lucerne, Switzerland launched its “Lucerne Shines” program, which rolled out mazes, hopscotch boxes, and three-point lines to make trash disposal a fun, interactive experience! The project appeals to kids and is a nostalgic throwback for adults alike.

Norwegian Architects Helen and Hard upcycled materials left by Stavanger's petroleum industry into a park that includes spaces for jumping, playing, skating, chilling out, and street art exhibitions. Geopark also helps activate the adjacent Oil Museum. Planned as a one-year installation, the space has gone on to become one of the country's most valued destinations.
Sign pole...or sundial? A great example of imbuing everyday urban fixtures with new, surprising functions from Maastricht!
